node.text:
Indigenous people in Minnesota get arrested for protesting the Line 3 pipeline at Red Lake Treaty Camp. This land belongs to the Indigenous people and the Line 3 pipeline will have serious long term effects on the environment. #StopLine3 via @davenewworld_2 on Twitter

Line 3 Pipeline: Line 3 is a proposed pipeline expansion to bring nearly a million barrels of tar sands per day from Alberta, Canada to Superior, Wisconsin. It was proposed in 2014 by Enbridge, a Canadian pipeline company responsible for the largest inland oil spill in the US. Enbridge seeks to build a new pipeline corridor through untouched wetlands and the treaty territory of Anishinaabe peoples, through the Mississippi River headwaters to the shore of Lake Superior. 

All pipelines spill. Line 3 isn’t about safe transportation of a necessary product, it’s about expansion of a dying tar sands industry. Line 3 would contribute more to climate change than Minnesota’s entire economy. Minnesota’s own Department of Commerce found our local market does not need Line 3 oil. We need to decommission the old Line 3 and justly transition to a renewable, sustainable economy.  Line 3 would violate the treaty rights of Anishinaabe peoples and nations in its path — wild rice is a centerpiece of Anishinaabe culture, it grows in numerous watersheds Line 3 seeks to cross. It’s well-past time to end the legacy of theft from and destruction of indigenous peoples and territories. 

via @goldenwolf5601 on TikTok (Follow us on Twitter to learn more, check stories to see what is happening and how you can help spread this information)

node.text:
New York City alone throws 1.4 Billion pounds of textiles each year including clothing, belts and shoes. 85% of that ends up in the landfills! (According to the NYC Department of Environmental Conservation)

We partnered with FARFETCH on a new project called Past Life where we highlight how clothes have many lives, so we begin caring for their past and future lives. A project to divert clothes from landfills.

A solution besides consuming less paired with buying less and wearing your clothes for longer can be to donate a piece of clothing via FARFETCH Donate -  a donation program that is part of the broader Positively FARFETCH strategy. 

The items donated will then be redistributed for meaningful use, rather than adding to the abundance of clothing waste.

A project by:
@farfetch x @theslowfactory

Directed by @sophfei
DP @agustinabiasutto
Edited by @wonseungii
AC @_eileeny_
Gaffer @lorenzopacedop
Sound @brauliolin
Hair @skimdo
Makeup @ayatariqmua @toodbeauty
Location @arkhous_bk
Music @collisbrowne

Special thanks to: ❤️

Kimberly Drew @museummammy
Mecca James-Williams @meccajw
Babba Rivera @babba
Maria Alia Al-sadek @mariaalia
Fran Tirado @fransquishco
Céline Semaan @celinecelines
Sophia Li @sophfei

node.text: Haunani K. Trask was a powerful leader who fought for the freedom and justice of the Hawaiien people, affirming the Hawaiian culture, identity and politics by speaking truth to power. We hold her in our hearts as she transitions with the ancestors, and we continue the fight.

node.title: We mourn the loss of legendary Haunani K. Trask

node.text:
Biden is NO climate hero, the Biden administration is supporting the largest tar sand pipeline in the world and the most expensive one estimated at $9B harassing and arresting Indigenous women and groups water protectors violating the treaties and their illegal occupation of their land to build and create new routes through Indigenous territories for the most environmentally toxic and destructive project: Alberta’s Tar Sands.

Repost from @democracynow
•
Thousands gathered for a Treaty People Gathering weekend of action to #StopLine3, which would carry more than 750,000 barrels of tar sands oil a day through Indigenous land and fragile ecosystems and endanger lakes, rivers and wild rice beds. More than 100 water protectors led by Indigenous Anishinaabe women were arrested Monday in northern Minnesota during the largest act of civil disobedience to date to halt the pipeline, which if completed, would be "the largest tar sands pipeline in the world," says Winona LaDuke, an Anishinaabe activist and executive director of @honortheearth. "We have a Canadian corporation coming in here trying to make a buck at the end of the fossil fuels era and run over a bunch of Indigenous people, and we're not having it."

node.title: Biden administration supports Canadian Tar San Illegal Pipeline

Sounds of your childhood with @ty_ushka exploring climate justice migration and climate refugees through sound. #worldoceansday Sounds of the waves 🌊

Shout out to @culturestrike “Lead with culture not policy” ❤️

📻 I Really Love this Song is a conceptual digital exhibition and visual mixtape curated by @theslowfactory commissioning twenty artists who are in their own right leading voices contributing in the on-going revolution at the intersection of climate and human rights. Powered with @drinkruna official media partner with @dazed #IReallyLoveThisSong 🌈

First 100 to get their free passes will receive a special gift curated by us 👀 including: 🦺 Special collection available for I Really Love this Song is made in partnership with @versiontomorrow

node.text:
Elgorithm’s ( @elgorithm )
Trauma Relief Fund

As part of the 10 month remember since of the Beirut Explosion, as well as the launch of Elgorithm’a Trauma Relief Fund, we’ve prepared a video on Lebanon’s mental health crisis.

“On August 4th 2020 two explosions erupted in the port of Beirut, Lebanon, which sent shockwaves across the city and beyond — people felt the impact up to 150 miles away, with individuals in neighboring island Cyprus reporting noise and rattling windows.

Lebanese homes, businesses and full city blocks were destroyed while thousands were injured and needed immediate care. Hospitals, which were already overwhelmed due to rising Covid-19 cases, are dealing with mass casualties despite limited resources. According to Al Jazeera, three hospitals were fully destroyed while two were damaged. The death toll is currently at 137 and rising, and 5,000 have been injured.” wrote @celinecelines for @voguemagazine the days following the deadly explosion

The final count of people killed because of this explosion amounts to 207, 300,000 were left homeless, 7,500 were injured.

Prioritizing trauma relief is central in healing our bodies and spirits in order to heal our land and city. Please consider supporting @elgorithm fund for Beirut.

node.text:
📌 Reposting this live between @ahmedeldin and @celinecelines, now with ASL interpretation and captions as promised 🤟❤️
. . .
In this live, the two demystify Free Palestine as a movement anchored in human rights for all, a movement at the end to antisemitism. They answer the age-old question “but Hamas?” and define urbicide: the action of destroying entire cities (Gaza) and the role of the media in the manipulation of truth and censorship.

node.text:
Temporarily saving this Live with @ahmedeldin here on IGTV so we can download it and add close captions & include our ASL interpreters—In this Live @celinecelines & @ahmedeldin demystify Free Palestine as a movement anchored in human rights for all, a movement at the opposite end to Anti-Semitism. We answer the age-old question “but Hamas” and define urbicide: the action of destroying entire cities (Gaza). The role of the Media and the manipulation of truth, censorship. We will be adding subtitles / ASL 

Stay tuned ✌️

node.text:
Celebrating Earth Day with a partnership with @pinterest x @theslowfactory discussing Peer to peer knowledge — Open Education ✏️ and the power of visual learning and images. Check out our Boards on Pinterest 1) Earth Day Archive 2) Open Education where all of our visual information is available as an open archive for all 🌎

EDUCATION IS THE FOUNDATION OF PROGRESS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Slow Factory 🌍 on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Open Edu what school won't teach you SF link in bio D Summer Camp Slow Factory Foundation x Vestiaire Collective'.

node.text:
Welcome to Open Edu Summer Camp 2021! ☀️🏖🍉
We’re so excited to share our August 2021 curriculum, featuring some absolutely astounding educators ✏ 

Open Edu is our open and equity-centered education initiative for Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic communities taught by Black, Brown, Indigenous and minority ethnic scholars, thinkers, and educators ♥️ 

We couldn’t be happier to say that Open Edu Summer Camp is FREE! Sign up for our newsletter and you’ll be in the loop about how to register for classes so you’ll never have to worry about missing anything.🗓 Link in bio ⬆️ ⬆️ 

Education is the foundation of progress, and Open Edu Summer Camp is all about teaching you what school won’t! We've partnered with Vestiaire Collective (@vestiaireco) to bring you a month of classes focused on the disposable culture of fast fashion. As students of life and critical thinkers, let's continue evolving and working to dismantle colonial systems of oppression 🤝 

Swipe to see the curriculum 👀 

🤘all classes will have ASL interpretation 

ID: 

Slide 1: white background and black text that reads “Open Edu Summer Camp” A bouncy , non-binary, yellow-red ombré figure is walking.  A small, black circle in the upper right-hand corner with white text reads “what school won’t teach you” . Icon for ASL Interpretation in bottom right corner to indicate access for every Open Edu class. Black text in the bottom left corner are partnership logos for Slow Factory Foundation x Vestiaire Collective 

Slide 2: graphic with white background and black text that reads “ Open Edu Summer Camp” in top left corner, beside it, an illustration of an orange/red staircase and polka-dotted squiggle in the background. Below,  the syllabus in b: “  Aug 6 - The History of Fast Fashion: How did this system take over? - Aja Barber/ Aug 13 - The Culture of Disposability: How did we make throwing good things away part of our culture? - Céline Semaan / Aug 20 - The History of Resale Markets: Throwing away clothes for a living - Liz Ricketts / Aug 27 - Open Edu Live Session: Town Hall Q&A - Ask Us Anything!” ID continued in comments ✏

node.text:
We believe that education is the foundation of progress and the first step in creating radical collective change. 

Though we know that these oppressive systems capitalize on what we popularize, we want to take a moment to remind you of what these systems and leaders fear the most…. 

LOVE AND IDEAS. 

Love frees us, and ideas allow us to truly imagine a possible future. A different future. 

So before this lends itself to marketing and greenwashing schemes, remember your power. Practice love and don’t be afraid of your big ideas!! 

Stay tuned for an exciting Open Edu announcement coming up!
@celinecelines @lov3ronica 🤟

node.text:
Indigenous people in Minnesota get arrested for protesting the Line 3 pipeline at Red Lake Treaty Camp. This land belongs to the Indigenous people and the Line 3 pipeline will have serious long term effects on the environment. #StopLine3 via @davenewworld_2 on Twitter

Line 3 Pipeline: Line 3 is a proposed pipeline expansion to bring nearly a million barrels of tar sands per day from Alberta, Canada to Superior, Wisconsin. It was proposed in 2014 by Enbridge, a Canadian pipeline company responsible for the largest inland oil spill in the US. Enbridge seeks to build a new pipeline corridor through untouched wetlands and the treaty territory of Anishinaabe peoples, through the Mississippi River headwaters to the shore of Lake Superior. 

All pipelines spill. Line 3 isn’t about safe transportation of a necessary product, it’s about expansion of a dying tar sands industry. Line 3 would contribute more to climate change than Minnesota’s entire economy. Minnesota’s own Department of Commerce found our local market does not need Line 3 oil. We need to decommission the old Line 3 and justly transition to a renewable, sustainable economy.  Line 3 would violate the treaty rights of Anishinaabe peoples and nations in its path — wild rice is a centerpiece of Anishinaabe culture, it grows in numerous watersheds Line 3 seeks to cross. It’s well-past time to end the legacy of theft from and destruction of indigenous peoples and territories. 

via @goldenwolf5601 on TikTok (Follow us on Twitter to learn more, check stories to see what is happening and how you can help spread this information)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Slow Factory 🌍 on July 26, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of outdoors and text that says 'Slow Factory Foundation What is a Climate Refugee? Q'.

node.text:
#repost to include all slides:

Both climate refugees and internal climate migrants refer to peoples who are displaced from their homes due to natural disasters and extreme environmental circumstances. 

In both cases, the countries and populations that are most severely affected are those least equipped to handle the effects of climate change. On average, these countries take in more than 90% of refugees and 70% of internally displaced people. 

This is an ongoing, daily, disaster, that is more than just an environmental issue. As climate change, conflict, and political and economic tension are inextricably connected, this is a human rights issue. 🌍 

🤝 We CAN curtail this crisis by focusing on prevention & actionable solutions.

Biden’s executive order for his administration to analyze, offer foreign aid, and devise solutions for the protection and resettlement of those affected & displaced due to climate change is a pivotal step in the right direction. 

Countries across the world are responsible to take similar steps so that those who are displaced can garner protection and support under international law. 

As always, preventative actions are most effective, so we’re calling for corporations, companies & governments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and consider climate migration in their development plans.

Promoting awareness and using clear and concise language to describe this growing and vulnerable population are essential to mitigate this crisis. ✊🏻✊🏼✊🏽✊🏾✊🏿

ID: 
Slide 1: Slow Factory definition card that reads: The term “climate refugee” refers to those who are forcibly displaced by natural disasters and other environmental catastrophes and must seek shelter and livelihood in other countries. Currently, climate refugees are not protected under international law, as the 1951 Refugee Convention does not recognize climate refugees as an at-risk population. Source: climaterefugees.org

✏️ continues in comments ⬇️

node.text:
We’re announcing Open Edu Summer Camp soon, and in the meantime, we have your next poolside read 📚☀️

We want you to be a part of our Slow Factory book club where we’ll be discussing the book, Pollution is Colonialism by Max Liboiron. Connect with us on our Slack, where we’ll be hosting our book club, to participate in thoughtful discussion, open conversations, and communion. Link in our bio to join.  ⬆️⬆️

About the Book: This book offers a framework for looking at existing scientific methods as they relate to, or reject colonialism. The premise of the book critiques pollution as an extension, rather than a symptom, of colonialism, and suggests that even with the best of intentions, environmentalism and climate activism often uphold colonial perspectives towards Indigenous land. Pollution is Colonialism exemplifies a refreshing scientific approach that is anti colonial and centers Indigenous land, ethics, and policies. 

About the Author: Max Liboiron is a pioneer in bringing anti-colonial views and methods to a variety of disciplines. She/they are the founder of CLEAR (@clear_lab_), an anti-colonial marine science laboratory centered on plastic pollution and good land relations. Their work is integral to enacting policy change and accountability in the plastics and indigenous research spaces, as well as to the development of the field of discard studies. Max Liboiron is an Associate Professor in Geography and the former Associate Vice-President of Indigenous Research at Memorial University.

ID: Open Edu Summer Camp book club announcement on what appears to be a library book, S in the background representing the Slow Factory logo. Words on the announcement read the name of the book: “Pollution is Colonialism” in the center,  with author’s name, ” Max Liboiron” in the bottom right hand corner.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Slow Factory 🌍 on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Slow Factory Foundation Inspiration or Imitation? An exploration of intellectual labor theft in the sustainability movement.'.

node.text:
Our goal is to co-create an anti-capitalist, participatory, and reciprocal landscape for all organizations working toward a better and brighter future. Aligning our practices with our sustainability values means honoring intellectual labor as well as physical labor. Let us build a  culture of respect, not erasure, for the global sustainability movement.

ID:

Slide 1: Inspiration or
Imitation?

An exploration of intellectual labor theft in the sustainability movement.

Slide 2: Labor exploitation also occurs in the sustainability movement.
This takes place in many forms:

	Paraphrasing ideas without citing sources
	Replication of programming
	Co-opting design of other organizations
	Appropriation of terminology
	Unpaid labor

Slide 3: These forms of labor theft harm individuals and organizations who spend years if not decades researching &
developing their ideas and theories of change (TOC).

✏️ Continues in comments

node.text:
[Edited] ICYMI Ben & Jerry’s (@benandjerrys ) announced it will not renew the license agreement with their manufacturer in occupied Palestine. This is a significant victory for the #bds movement and proof that the growing mainstream support for a #FreePalestine is creating change.

❌ HOWEVER, We’re ambivalent about some of the fine print, so we’ll be watching closely to make sure @benandjerrys follows through on the spirit of the commitment. Divesting from the Israeli apartheid regime must be more than performative action couched in technicalities. 🍦

ID: A vintage Ben & Jerry’s ad campaign remixed by the Slow Factory team, instead of the traditional “brownies that do good” it is replaced with “Decolonization never tasted so sweet. It starts with land back” A Palestinian flag is seen on the horizon.

node.text:
We had to pop in here, we’ve been away for two weeks — find us on Twitter where we share more information daily! Would love to hear how you’ve all been coping with the avalanche of terrible news regarding climate chaos. 

ID: twitter screenshot from @BrentToderian "Life imitating art warning about death #ClimateCrisis with two similar images. Left: Art 2014: Politicians discussing global warming. Photograph of art by Isaac Cordal @isaaccordal We see perhaps a dozen old white men in a huddle, submerged in water to the shoulders or over their heads. Right: Reality, 2021. News image of recent flooding in Germany showing a group of mostly older white men & women submerged to their torso and neck struggling in a city street.

node.text:
New York City alone throws 1.4 Billion pounds of textiles each year including clothing, belts and shoes. 85% of that ends up in the landfills! (According to the NYC Department of Environmental Conservation)

We partnered with FARFETCH on a new project called Past Life where we highlight how clothes have many lives, so we begin caring for their past and future lives. A project to divert clothes from landfills.

A solution besides consuming less paired with buying less and wearing your clothes for longer can be to donate a piece of clothing via FARFETCH Donate -  a donation program that is part of the broader Positively FARFETCH strategy. 

The items donated will then be redistributed for meaningful use, rather than adding to the abundance of clothing waste.

A project by:
@farfetch x @theslowfactory

Directed by @sophfei
DP @agustinabiasutto
Edited by @wonseungii
AC @_eileeny_
Gaffer @lorenzopacedop
Sound @brauliolin
Hair @skimdo
Makeup @ayatariqmua @toodbeauty

node.text: Haunani K. Trask was a powerful leader who fought for the freedom and justice of the Hawaiien people, affirming the Hawaiian culture, identity and politics by speaking truth to power. We hold her in our hearts as she transitions with the ancestors, and we continue the fight.

Individual action vs. Collective systemic action—true change is revolution / land back / systemic regenerative change. tweet & graphic by @checarina on twitter 

id: The tweet reads “did i do this right “ an image of the fire in the middle of the ocean in the golf of mexico with rescue surrounding the fire, each boat has a word associated to it “no plastic straws” “turn off your AC” and “recycling”
